content: How to be a -10x Engineertaylor.townaboutnowrssnewshnhiremeetemailHow to be a -10x Engineer+10x engineers may be mythical, but -10x engineers exist.To become a -10x engineer, simply waste 400 engineering hours per week. Combine the following strategies:Nullify the output of 10 engineers.Change requirements as far into development as possible. To avoid blame, obfuscate requirements from the start.Create 400 hours of busywork.Ask your team to perform tasks that resemble work. Common examples include presentations, diagrams, and ticket management. Create pointless rituals.Create 400 hours of burnout/turnover.Be thankless. Foist blame. Sow confusion. Get angry. Cause others to work overtime.Hold 10 engineers hostage in a technical discussion.Let engineers discuss ideas. Encourage them to pursue elegance over pragmatism. Ensure nobody has the authority to make any decisions.Add 400 hours of communication overhead.Meetings wreck calendars. To inconspicuously waste others’ time, write lengthy messages/documents and share as widely as possible. Welcome all opinions and aim for engagement.Waste 10 weeks of wages on cloud costs.Write slow programs. Avoid DB indexes. Run single-threaded programs on 16-core machines. Opt for exotic hardware with fancy RAM and GPUs. Store data on RAM/disk liberally. Don’t compress anything. Pay no attention to data layouts.Create useless tools.Decide that existing solutions aren’t quite what you need. Write scripts that only one person understands. If the script does something important, avoid documentation.Add 400 hours of compilation/build time.Slow builds waste time and incur compound interest. As build times increase, developers are more likely to distract themselves. To ensure developers are context-switching, recompilation should take at least 20 seconds. You can also write slow tests for similar effect.Write pointless tests.Create dependencies on particular variables without testing the underlying functionality. Mock function calls until no original code runs. Introduce subtle randomness into your tests so that they succeed/fail without cause.Waste 400 hours of engineering on bad architecture.Give zero consideration to how your system design will evolve over time. Alternatively, drive your team obsess over architecture decisions so that they don’t have time to test their hypotheses.Waste 400 hours on deployment.Create as many environments as possible. Production and staging must differ wildly. Launch fragile code with fragile build systems. Migrate your databases frequently.Lose 10 weeks of wages on unhappy customers.Repeatedly fail to detect and address severe bugs. Pay no attention to security vulnerabilities.Write worthless documentation.Explain code in private messages. Write wikis that nobody uses.Trap 10 engineers in a futile skunkworks project.Attract bright engineers and waste their potential. Undersell the difficulty of the project to management; oversell the project’s usefulness. Tell management it’s “almost complete” until they scrap it.Add dependencies that demand 400 hours of maintenance.Engineers individually learn each library.Delay pivoting.Never admit failure. Drown your team in sunk-cost. Ignore 80/20 compromises that could improve your circumstances.Hire 10 0x engineers.Opportunity costs can kill. Dead-weights may not actively harm your team, but they sit in the chairs of people who could actively help.Hire 5 -1x engineeers.Don’t settle for dead-weight. Actively hire engineers who cause catastrophies and resist learning.Prevent 10 -1x engineers from getting fired.Don’t rock boats. Leave no paper trail of failures. Vouch for bad engineering.Incur 400 hours of bug triage.Make undebuggable programs. Plaster layers of abstraction over everything. Write spaghetti code. Make everything sensitive to initial conditions. Avoid pure functions. Use dependencies liberally. Say “it works on my machine” whenever possible.Subscribe to my monthly newsletter.Discuss this page on HackerNews.Schedule a 30-minute chat.Subscribe to my RSS feed.Send me an e-mail.

Home                News                Catan         Creator of Catan, Klaus Teuber, has passed away at the age of 70“Contributions to board gaming industry are immeasurable.”    Image: Rogi Lensing             News         by Alex Meehan            Senior Staff Writer          Published on April 4, 2023 2 comments          About Catan   Released: 1995   Players: 3-4   Rules complexity: Low   Strategic depth: LowKlaus Teuber, the designer responsible for creating Catan, has passed away at the age of 70.In a press release from Catan Studios – the company behind the release of the family board game – it was confirmed that Teuber had passed on April 1st following a “brief and severe illness.” The news comes as a shock, considering the designer had been creating new expansions and versions of Catan that are set to be released later this year.In response to Teuber’s death, Catan Studios released a statement calling the Catan creator a “legendary figure in the board gaming industry,” who had not only designed one of the most well-known tabletop series in modern history but had “shaped the genre of the ‘German Game.’ [and] will continue to inspire generations of gamers for years to come.” Catan Studio head, Pete Fenlon, said “While Klaus’ contributions to the board gaming industry are immeasurable, we will remember him as a kind and selfless human being, an inspirational leader, and most importantly, as a friend.”Teuber designed Catan – then called Settlers of Catan – in 1995, having previously designed several lesser-known tabletop titles such as Barbarossa in 1988 and Hoity Toity in 1990. Catan has become one of the most popular board games released in the past 30 years, winning the coveted Spiel des Jahres award in 1995 – the most prestigious award in the tabletop industry - with the series enduring to this day thanks to over 50 expansions, spin-offs and revised versions of the title being published since its launch.In Catan, three to four players attempt to establish and develop their own civilisations on a fictional island. Depending on where players choose to place their settlements, they’ll receive certain resources whenever a particular number is rolled at the start of every player’s turn. Using these resources, players can construct additional settlements, as well as new roads. Players can also upgrade their existing settlements into cities to acquire victory points.Watch on YouTube  Lolies teaches you how to play Catan.Should players ever struggle to obtain particular types of resources, they can try to trade with their fellow players – as long as they can agree on a deal – or with one of the various ports on the board. content: Supercentenarian and remarkable age records exhibit patterns indicative of clerical errors and pension fraud | bioRxivSkip to main content HomeAboutSubmitALERTS / RSS Search for this keyword Advanced Search      New Results  Supercentenarian and remarkable age records exhibit patterns indicative of clerical errors and pension fraud View ORCID ProfileSaul Justin Newmandoi: https://doi.org/10.1101/704080 Saul Justin Newman 1Biological Data Science Institute, Australian National UniversityFind this author on Google ScholarFind this author on PubMedSearch for this author on this siteORCID record for Saul Justin NewmanFor correspondence: saul.newman@anu.edu.au AbstractFull TextInfo/HistoryMetricsSupplementary material Preview PDF AbstractThe observation of individuals attaining remarkable ages, and their concentration into geographic sub-regions or ‘blue zones’, has generated considerable scientific interest. Proposed drivers of remarkable longevity include high vegetable intake, strong social connections, and genetic markers. Here, we reveal new predictors of remarkable longevity and ‘supercentenarian’ status. In the United States supercentenarian status is predicted by the absence of vital registration. In the UK, Italy, Japan, and France remarkable longevity is instead predicted by regional poverty, old-age poverty, material deprivation, low incomes, high crime rates, a remote region of birth, worse health, and fewer 90+ year old people. In addition, supercentenarian birthdates are concentrated on the first of the month and days divisible by five: patterns indicative of widespread fraud and error. As such, relative poverty and missing vital documents constitute unexpected predictors of centenarian and supercentenarian status, and support a primary role of fraud and error in generating remarkable human age records.Competing Interest StatementThe authors have declared no competing interest.FootnotesRevised to capture over 80% of people exceeding age 110 in the world, analyze over 50,000 centenarians, and provide predictive models of the density of remarkable age records. hn_content: Vinylrecorder.com explains how the left and right signals of a stereo record were recorded in opposite phase to allow existing mono players to play stereo recordings and to permit stereo players to play older mono records. Furthermore, an early dynamic spacing compression technology that was nearly double the typical record's running time is presented. As well as this, comments mention various details such as the FM radio's elegant solution and the lower bandwidth of the A-B channel, and further resources that may intrigue those interested in cutting-edge record groove technology.A YouTube channel focuses on delivering technology content at a slow pace; some viewers find it dorky, while others appreciate the more relaxed approach. The physicality and the permanence of vinyl records appeal to some music listeners, especially when compared to more ephemeral mediums like MP3s. Vinyl is said to provide a different, more active and focused listening experience than digitals, which tend to be more algorithmically curated. Record sales have surpassed CD sales as music lovers gravitate towards high-quality sound and tangible connections with artists. The slow pace and sophomoric definition of stereo in a video explanation is received as condescending by some viewers.Vinyl mastering engineer rolls up the bass level on the EQ over the length of the side as the record is cut. Quadraphonic CD-4 records from the 1970s encode 4 discrete channels into a single record groove with two additional channels on a 30kHz carrier signal above human hearing range. The mid-side technique is used elsewhere, besides record grooves, including compressed audio files, signal processing chains in the studio, and certain stereo microphone recording techniques. Stereo vinyl records are recorded with vertical groove profile as V=L+R and horizontal as H=L-R, backward compatible with older mono gramophones that read only L+R and stereo players do H+V=2L and H-V=2R to decode. Magnetic sound recording is just running past a speaker coil at a constant speed while holding something long and ferrous next to it, and to play it back, do the same thing but plug the coil into the input. Dolby Pro Logic II stereo signal can encode a surround sound signal. Mono is better for 12" dance records due to avoiding stereo image/balance effects in clubs, and avoiding phase effects between speakers in multi-speaker setups.Users on Hacker News discuss the possibility of encoding digital data onto vinyl records. Some commenters suggest it could work, potentially with lossless compression and utilizing ultrasonic frequencies. Others point out that vinyl records with digital processing already exist, while some discuss the history of quadraphonic records. hn_content: A Hacker News post argues that e-bikes should be the focus of our electric vehicle efforts, but some argue that it's about infrastructure, not vehicles. Commenters discuss the need for infrastructure changes to accommodate e-bikes, including painting bike lanes, adding charging stations, and re-engineering cities. Others point out that changing infrastructure is affordable and could ultimately be beneficial for the health of the population and local business. One user suggests focusing on only allowing EVs in city cores, while another argues that the existing car infrastructure was subsidized for fossil fuels, and it's time to make changes.A writer discusses how they were able to use a non-electric bike as their primary mode of transportation, even with a BMI of 46, in their relatively flat hometown of Dresden, Germany. An HN user mentions the percentage of Americans who don't know how to ride a bike as compared to those with a license. Others discuss why adults may not enjoy biking regularly, including issues with safety and weather. Some believe that if infrastructure and accessibility improved, more adults may begin to ride bikes regularly, as seen in New York City.A discussion on the benefits and challenges of cycling infrastructure has taken place on Hacker News. While some argue that focusing on bicycles is an odd choice and ignores the needs of those who cannot ride a bike, others suggest that bikes can help people with health issues and offers an eco-friendly, cheap mode of transportation. An HN user points out that cycling infrastructure can benefit people with disabilities and children. The discussion touches on the potential need for a transition that spans generations, as different types of personal transport converge. There is debate around the idea that bikes are accessible to most of the population, and some believe that cars are still the most practical choice for many Americans.A discussion on Hacker News about investing in biking infrastructure to encourage healthier modes of transportation sparking mixed reactions from readers. While some believe it could lead to improvements in infrastructure and health, others argue that snow and the risk of falling make biking too dangerous, particularly for older people. One commenter claims that the enduring popularity of articles on Hacker News about biking just shows demographic bias towards young, city-dwelling readers. Additionally, another comments that while cars may be great on an individual scale, they are bad on a societal scale, encouraging bad design, wasting space, and causing danger to bicyclists and pedestrians.Comments on a Hacker News post argue that while nobody wants to do away with all motor infrastructure, allocating roads for smaller, slower bicycle and bicycle-like traffic could transform cities for the better. E-bikes specifically are praised for making it easier to commute in any weather, providing cheaper and more efficient transport in cities, and allowing people to shift to a more eco-friendly lifestyle without sacrificing much of their previous conveniences. However, some are still worried about theft in urban environments.Bicycle theft is prevalent due to a lack of enforcement and the low value of bikes. While a secure home contents policy can cover theft outside the home, bike owners should take precautions like the Sheldon brown locking technique, anti-theft bolts and using GPS. Some suggest GPS could help police locate stolen bikes, but enforcement without registration may prove difficult. Others propose secure bike lockers or bigger ones to deter theft. Organized gangs move bikes across borders, increasing police pressure on them along with soft penalties for theft. Lastly, some tech can help resist bike theft, like software-defined bikes.The lack of adequate bike parking infrastructure in several cities has led to a public policy failure that impacts the usability of bikes as an eco-friendly and cost-effective vehicle. Commentators note that while e-bikes are replacing traditional bikes, they aren't yet changing the way people move, given that car traffic volumes have unequivocally risen in the post-pandemic world. One user points out that what we need is e-bike standards for the components, given the current lack of standardization and the exorbitant costs of replacing broken parts. Nonetheless, e-bikes are growing in popularity as they outsell electric cars, motorbikes, vans, busses and trucks combined, with Lemonade offering bike insurance for a low monthly rate of $7.The debate in the comments section focuses on the standardization of components in the bike industry, particularly in regards to motors and batteries. While there are many standardized components, there are also many different standards for each type of component. An open system that allows third-party manufacturers to build motors and batteries to be interchangeable with existing bikes would be ideal. One user shares their personal experience of using an ebike for commuting, expressing that ebikes are a fun, healthy, and fast mode of transportation, particularly for trips under 15km. The main barriers to promoting bike commuting are incompetence and malice, as politicians may not understand the benefits of bike lanes and incumbents in the transport industry may resist change.An HN user believes that policies promoting e-fuel are contradictory, and rather we should focus on sharing the pie fairly. HN users discuss the issue of bike theft and suggest that e-bike bike shares or cheap alternatives could be solutions. Another user suggests geo-trackers in bikes for theft prevention. E-bikes have divided opinions, some see them as unnecessary and unsafe, while others view them as facilitating the adoption of bikes as a mode of transportation. Some users believe "cars" cause similar issues to e-bikes in terms of letting inexperienced operators go too fast.Experts on Hacker News discuss the experience of bike riders in North America and provide better solutions for getting respect on the road. Anecdotal evidence suggests that taking the lane as a cyclist helps to reduce close passes from drivers. Many commenters express support for e-bikes, sharing experiences of using them as an alternative to cars for commuting. While e-bikes are seen as useful for replacing some car trips, they are not a complete replacement due to the speed, range, and hauling capabilities of cars. Some discuss the need to reduce the size and weight of cars in order to promote safer and more sustainable transportation.Replacing a car with an e-bike may not be practical for everyone due to lifestyle and weather factors. Congress's decision to limit the tax credit on e-bikes over $4,000 is not entirely accurate as there are still cargo e-bikes available for less than the maximum limit. The use of e-bikes provides some exercise benefits, although not comparable to a strenuous workout. The argument that people can bike in snowy conditions similar to Finland may not be practical for everyone, and Finnish infrastructure is unique to the country. Financial incentives to switch from cars to cargo e-bikes may not be enough for Americans to make the switch. Encouragement for people to use e-bikes for short distances and to provide accessible parking options may help promote e-bike usage.An HN user points out that electric bikes could supplement cars rather than replace them, saving money and the environment. Bike riders forget that not everyone can operate a bike in all weather conditions; we need more micromobility options of all shapes and sizes. Small, enclosed, and electric cars could be a potential solution for people's transportation needs. In cities, bike lanes and scooter racks should be available for public use. Protected bike lanes are vital for biker safety. There is a lot of space for bike lanes in the US, and bike racks are cheaper than car parking spots.Some Hacker News users discuss the challenges of using e-bikes, particularly in harsh weather conditions or areas with high rates of bike theft. Various leading e-bike brands are also critiqued for their custom-made components and maintenance issues, with some users advocating for building one's own e-bike using standardized parts like Bosch and Shimano. Despite potential drawbacks, personal electric vehicles like e-bikes and electric scooters can provide convenient and sustainable transportation options for short trips and commuting.Experts on Hacker News discuss the benefits and drawbacks of e-bikes and e-scooters compared to traditional bikes. While some users argue that e-bikes are expensive and lead to waste, others suggest that they provide easier commutes, especially for those who aren't fit or have longer distances to travel. Critics note that e-bikes can be difficult to control, and some models are prone to accidents or have substandard safety features. Users in Sweden point out that the government offers incentives for those looking to purchase e-bikes, although this program was only available in 2018.E-bikes are more efficient than traditional bikes, filling a critical niche towards minimising dependence on cars, according to a Tech Times journalist. Cargo carrying is generally better with traditional bikes, especially in cities with rolling hills and modern heat islands. A number of HN users voiced their opinions on the feasibility of e-bikes for urban mobility. Overall, one user believed that e-bikes replace a majority of car usages, while another preferred unicycles for their manoeuvrability and lacking the need for parking spaces.
hn_summary: A Hacker News post argues for e-bikes as the focus of EV efforts, and commenters debate the need for infrastructure changes. Some believe that changing infrastructure could benefit public health and local business. Issues with safety and weather may hinder the wider adoption of biking, but better accessibility may result in more regular biking. The lack of adequate bike parking and bike theft is another issue hindering the usability of bikes for transportation. Experts discuss the standardization of components and potential barriers to promoting e-bike commuting. E-bikes offer convenience and sustainability, but some users remain critical of their safety and cost. Solutions such as geo-trackers and e-bike bike shares are being proposed to address theft. Despite the potential drawbacks, personal EVs like e-bikes and electric scooters provide efficient and eco-friendly modes of transportation.

hn_content: Cheap, tiny smart speakers have played a crucial role in the rise of digital payments in India, making it easier for shopkeepers to accept e-payments. The speakers eliminate the need for shopkeepers to fiddle with their phones to confirm that they have received payment, since the device just reads out the amount, which the customer can verify before leaving. Indians living abroad need to keep an Indian phone number active to use UPI or use India-issued cards, so digital payments can be pretty inconvenient for visitors. Tourists from G20 countries can use UPI at select international airports.Paytm has launched a device in India that aims to help vendors and retailers that may struggle with technology to take payments. The speaker device simply says the amount received out loud, eliminating the need for the vendor to be able to read or write, or check their phone to confirm payment. Commenters suggested that a simple screen display could work just as effectively. Vendors use the device because they do not like having to check their phone every time there is a payment, particularly when busy, and the device is also relatively cheap to operate. Some vendors, however, in India are already accepting payments via smartphones without the need for a speaker device.A street vendor device is gaining popularity in India for its usefulness in making payment transactions. The small device, which resembles a tea kettle, alerts vendors to transactions made using payment apps with a notification chime and can be connected to a speaker for a louder alert. Some users of the device suggest that it is more convenient than using a smartphone, which could be lost, taken, or drained of battery. Meanwhile, debate on literacy rates in India and the U.S. has arisen, with indications that measures of literacy standards may differ significantly between the two nations.India's low literacy rate has led fintech companies to use audio-based payment confirmation systems targeting its niche illiterate population. Illiteracy remains high around the world, including regions such as Africa, where digital payments have already gone big. Funding education remains a challenge as politicians lack motivation to change how schools are funded, resisting empowering local entities to improve education. However, having good educational opportunities does not always translate into better literacy rates, with some people struggling to read and write due to functional difficulties or denial. Commentators suggest not only focusing on society's failures but also considering what can be done by individuals.A soundbox developed by Indian payment app PhonePe is helping small merchants in the country fight fraud and accept digital payments with greater ease. The secure device attaches to the merchant’s smartphone and announces when transactions are made, removing the need for the merchant to read their device’s screen. Over 500,000 Indian merchants now use the technology, which has also been praised for enabling instant, small loans for vendors requiring stock replenishment.The PayTM device in India uses a speaker to confirm digital payments audibly, making it easier for shopkeepers to receive payments and reduce fraud. The device is cheap and efficient, solving one specific problem. It costs less than a USD a month, making it affordable for many shops, and subscription fees help create a new revenue stream. Digital payment transactions in India stand at 8.5B per month, which is impressive. However, claims that globalists want to enslave India are unfounded and irrelevant to the topic at hand.

These speakers read out the payment amount, eliminating the need for manual confirmation. PayTM and PhonePe have created speaker devices connected to smartphones to benefit small vendors who face technical challenges. Some vendors in India are already using smartphones to accept payments. Audio-based payment systems are also targeting the country's low literacy rate. Digital payment transactions in India have reached an impressive 8.5B per month. Claims of globalists wanting to enslave India are irrelevant to the topic.

In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles      and JavaScript.AdvertisementView all journalsSearchLog inExplore contentAbout the journalPublish with usSubscribeSign up for alertsRSS feednaturenewsarticleNEWS03 April 2023‘This shouldn’t be happening’: levels of banned CFCs rising          Researchers have detected increased emissions for five ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons.                Katherine BourzacKatherine BourzacView author publicationsYou can also search for this author in PubMed Google ScholarTwitterFacebookEmailYou have full access to this article via your institution.Download PDFResearchers detected a surprising rise in levels of chlorofluorocarbons between 2010 and 2020 using a monitoring network that includes the Jungfraujoch research station in Switzerland.Credit: ShutterstockThe Montreal Protocol, which banned most uses of ozone-destroying chemicals known as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and called for their global phase-out by 2010, has been a great success story: Earth’s ozone layer is projected to recover by the 2060s.So atmospheric chemists were surprised to see a troubling signal in recent data. They found that the levels of five CFCs rose rapidly in the atmosphere from 2010 to 2020. Their results are published today in Nature Geoscience1.The chemists policing Earth’s atmosphere for rogue pollution“This shouldn’t be happening,” says Martin Vollmer, an atmospheric chemist at the Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology in Dübendorf who helped to analyse data from an international network of CFC monitors. “We expect the opposite trend, we expect them to slowly go down.”At current levels, these CFCs do not pose much threat to the ozone layer’s healing, said Luke Western, a chemist at the University of Bristol, UK, at an online press conference on 30 March. CFCs, once used as refrigerants and aerosols, can persist in the atmosphere for hundreds of years. Given that they are potent greenhouse gases, eliminating emissions of these CFCs will also have a positive impact on Earth’s climate. The collective annual warming effect of these five chemicals on the planet is equivalent to the emissions produced by a small country like Switzerland.It’s highly likely that manufacturing plants are accidently releasing three of the chemicals — CFC-113a, CFC-114a and CFC-115 — while producing replacements for CFCs. When CFCs were phased out, hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) were brought in as substitutes. But CFCs can crop up as unintended by-products during HFC manufacture. This accidental production is discouraged by the Montreal Protocol, but not prohibited by it.“A lot of this probably boils down to the factory level,” Vollmer says, pointing out that HFC production is on the rise. “A factory can be run relatively clean or relatively dirty.”Eyes on the skiesThe rise in the levels of the two other CFCs is a mystery. “CFC-13 and CFC-112a should not currently be used or produced,” says Rona Thompson, an atmospheric scientist at the Norwegian Institute for Air Research in Kjeller who was not involved in the analysis.The researchers speculate that levels of CFC-112a might be on the rise because of its use as a solvent or as a chemical feedstock. However, they say they need to discuss this idea further with chemical engineers to confirm that assessment.Illegal CFC emissions have stopped since scientists raised alarmBut the appearance of CFC-13 is much more baffling. “We really have no clue” where the emissions are coming from, Vollmer says. “We don’t know of any chemical process where this will show up as a by-product.” And, because there aren’t enough monitoring stations around the globe, it is difficult to pinpoint where this and the other CFC emissions are coming from, Thompson says.Nonetheless, Andreas Engel, an atmospheric scientist at Goethe University Frankfurt in Germany, says this research shows that the global monitoring system is largely working. Scientists are keeping a close watch on the planet’s atmosphere and spotting problems. “We just need to find out where it is coming from and then people will be willing and obliged to fix it,” Engel says.This is what happened a few years ago, when researchers detected high levels of CFC-11 in the atmosphere2, and traced them to eastern China3. They deduced the source on the basis of readings from monitoring stations in South Korea and Japan, reporting it in May 2019, and afterwards, levels began to fall. Scientists got somewhat lucky with CFC-11: monitoring stations equipped to detect that particular chemical happened to be located relatively close to the source.China feels the heat over rogue CFC emissionsEngel says it would help to increase the coverage of CFC-monitoring stations — for instance, the continents of Africa and South America have little if any coverage.If most emissions of the five recently detected CFCs are coming from the production of CFC-replacement chemicals, the world might need to think differently about HFCs, and perhaps even the next-generation of refrigerant chemicals — hydrofluoroolefins (HFOs) — Vollmer says. HFO production can emit CFCs too, he says.And if the problem continues, Vollmer adds, amendments might be needed to the Montreal Protocol to address this by-product problem head-on.“What this does show is that we need to keep our eyes open,” Engel says. “The story is not over.”doi: https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-00940-2ReferencesWestern, L. summary: Researchers have found that levels of five banned CFCs have risen rapidly from 2010 to 2020, contradicting the successful Montreal Protocol that had called for their global phase-out by 2010. The CFCs are not currently a threat to the ozone layer's healing, but their impact on Earth's climate is significant, calling for additional concern. Chemical production could be causing the accidental release of three chemicals, while the root cause of the other two chemicals' elevation remains unknown, suggesting that increased global monitoring of CFCs is necessary. The article highlights the need to keep a close watch on the atmosphere's dangers, and possible amendments to the Montreal Protocol to address the by-product problem head-on may be needed.

hn_content: Levels of banned CFCs are rising, according to a report. The increase of CFC-13 emissions is particularly concerning since there are no known chemical processes that would produce it. The report suggests that managing refrigerants is a top solution to limit warming. The warming effect of CFCs is equivalent to the emissions produced by a small country like Switzerland. The anticipated impact of CFC emissions on stratospheric ozone recovery is minor, but ongoing emissions may negate some of the benefits gained under the Montreal Protocol if they continue to rise. Both the ozone hole and global warming matter.Experts refute the claim that record snowpacks are evidence against global warming due to the phenomenon of climate change, which happens as a result of energy input from the system. A lack of studies on pre-CFC UV exposure methods, as well as early adaptations, made it hard to calculate their effects. There is a mismatch of incentives between factories, politicians, regulations or enforcement and individuals, who bear the risk of skin cancer. China has also been called out as a potential culprit in HFC and CFC production, with progressive climate change policies in Western countries facing an impenetrable barrier to implementation in totalitarian societies.Comments on Hacker News discuss potential ways to address environmental concerns related to the production of goods in countries with less regulation. Suggestions include starting with products with a known environmental impact and imposing escalating tariffs on noncompliant nations, although some warn of potential economic consequences. The discussion also touches on nuclear power as a potential solution to the energy crisis. However, there is debate over whether diplomatic means are effective in convincing other nations to lower their carbon emissions.A call for tariffs on goods produced by states who prioritize polluting power generation and potential immigration quotas for their citizens based on emission standards. The US and China's emission comparison shows a decrease in the US per capita emissions (-27%) starting 1973 and a decrease in the country's emission overall since 2007 (-13%), whereas for the same period, China has had a 7x increase per capita since 1973 (+532%) and 48% increase for its global emission since 2007. A suggestion to regulate our supply chains and pressure manufacturers elsewhere, with carbon taxes representing an actual solution instead of holding up a futile fight we're having now in efforts to address climate change. The complexity of energy systems and non-human incentives obscure simple solutions to ecological problems. Fracturing the world into the West and China negates ecological forces that affect the planet. Consumers must buy things with a transparent supply chain, look for ESG reports on their purchases and boycott China. Economic sanctions alone are insufficient; China and India must cooperate. Therefore, a carbon tariff on goods imported from dirty countries to make their goods less competitive and to provide incentives for clean manufacturing can be considered. Similarly, a minimum VAT tax can serve as a stepping stone towards closing down several tax loopholes.An HN user points out that while the United States has been reducing emissions, China hasn't been doing enough, and that as a nation we pollute twice as much as China, even if we outsource some of our pollution to China by having them do our manufacturing. The consequences of climate change are growing worse, and the US risks being left behind in sustainability efforts. The general sentiment is that solutions must be reached, not piecemeal progress, and that the discussion of alternative solutions should not be watered-down by generalizations such as EVs for all. It is important to weigh emission output by population and trade to account for outsourced emissions. The urgency to begin prevention initiatives is suggested to avoid a potential decrease in personal quality of life, even if the cost and implementation of such initiatives may be difficult.An HN discussion on fighting climate change with comments ranging from questioning the effectiveness of individual actions, the importance of taking responsibility for past emissions, and the potential for wealthy nations' investment in renewable energy to spur adoption in developing countries. The discussion also touches on the idea of whether or not Westerners should be making sacrifices to fight climate change while other major population centers continue to grow increasingly wealthy. The conversation highlights the need for a long-term global effort to address climate change and the potential for green technologies to be adopted by developing nations.Experts warn that China's ongoing lack of effort towards climate change may actually put them in a winning position when global standards are finally enforced, due to their investments in green technology. An HN user suggests that China may not be accurately reporting CO2, HFCs, and CFCs. Others speculate that perhaps old equipment and landfills are leaking the banned chemicals, while another user suggests that companies may be hoarding stockpiles of the substances. The ban on CFCs is praised as a success, and experts urge finding culprits to pressure into complying with international goals. Concerns over transitioning off petroleum are also discussed.

title: LangChain Announces 10M Seed Round
content: Announcing our $10M seed round led by Benchmark            LangChain        HomeAboutGitHubDocsAnnouncing our $10M seed round led by BenchmarkLangChainApr 4, 2023• 4 min readIt was only six months ago that we released the first version of LangChain, but it seems like several years. When we launched, generative AI was starting to go mainstream: stable diffusion had just been released and was captivating people’s imagination and fueling an explosion in developer activity, Jasper announced a funding round, and investors released the first Gen AI market maps.Alongside this boon in content creation, people started to realize that the true power of this technology was not using a language model in isolation, but using the language model as part of a new, more intelligent system. Developers were discussing how to connect language models to their own proprietary documents, APIs, and structured data. Research papers like Self-Ask with Search and ReAct were published, demonstrating the power of these approaches.Amongst these early tremors of a tectonic shift in computing, we released the first version of the LangChain Python package on October 24th, 2022. In the very first tweet thread, Harrison said:“a python package aimed at helping build LLM applications through composability”“The real power comes when you are able to combine [LLMs] with other things.”“LangChain aims to help with that by creating… a comprehensive collection of pieces you would ever want to combine… a flexible interface for combining pieces into a single comprehensive ‘chain’”Why Raise Funding?This all started as an open-source side project, without any intention of building a company. It began by noticing common patterns in how people were approaching problems, and attempting to create abstractions that made it easier. These first simple abstractions struck a chord and the project took off, thanks largely to your community support and contributions. LangChain now has over 20K stars on GitHub, 10K active Discord members, over 30K followers on Twitter, and - most importantly - over 350 contributors.It became clear that the combination of LangChain + LLMs blows open the frontier of amazing products and applications to be built. And, it also is clear that far more work and tooling are needed to make these applications work well (particularly in production). You’re asking us every day for more (400+ GitHub issues, 100 open PRs) and we want to help!With that in mind, we are excited to publicly announce that we have raised $10 million in seed funding. Benchmark led the round and we’re thrilled to have their counsel as they’ve been the first lead investors in some of the iconic open source software we all use including Docker, Confluent, Elastic, Clickhouse and more. With this capital we are going to invest aggressively to keep up with the ground breaking work the community is doing building intelligent apps. Our goal is simple: empower developers to build useful applications powered by language models.So what can you expect from us?LangChain TodayLangChain is a framework for developing applications powered by language models, offered as both a Python and a TypeScript package. We believe that the most powerful and differentiated language model applications will:Be data-aware: connect a language model to other sources of dataBe agentic: allow a language model to interact with its environmentThe LangChain framework is designed with the above objective principles in mind. We believe that the two main value props it provides are:ComponentsLangChain offers a modular set of abstractions and components that provide everything developers need to build applications using language models. It also includes collections of implementations for these abstractions.These components are largely community driven. There are over 300 contributors on the Python repo alone. Some highlights:Integrations with 20+ different model providers or hosting platformsCollection of 50+ Document Loaders to load data from different sourcesCollection of 10+ methods for splitting text data into chunks so that a Language Model can easily use itIntegrations with 10+ different vector databasesCollection of 15+ different tools to let Language Models usePre-built Chains and AgentsChains allow developers to assemble components in a specific manner to accomplish a particular task, such as summarizing a large pdf document or querying a SQL database. Agents can be thought of as “dynamic chains” in which the sequence of steps taken are determined by a language model on the fly. In addition to providing a high-level interface that makes it easy for developers to create custom chains and agents, LangChain provides many pre-built ones that can be used out-of-the-box.Again, these components are largely community driven. Some highlights:Implementations of ~20 different chainsImplementations of 6 different generic agent types (chains specifically designed to use tools and interact with the outside world)Implementations of 7 different “Agent Toolkits” (agents equipped with a specific set of tools to accomplish a specific task)Future PlansAs mentioned earlier, we believe that language models are unlocking new types of high-value applications, and it is still non-trivial to create and maintain these applications — particularly in production settings. Some of our more recent releases are focused on addressing these problems:Bringing the TypeScript package up to feature parity with Python to enable more full-stack and frontend developers to create LLM applicationsImplementing several types of OutputParsers, to allow for more safety and guidance on the text returned by a LLMIntroducing a Retriever abstraction to enable more complicated and necessary types of document retrievalBuilding integrations with solutions like Weights & Biases, AIM, ClearML to enable more observability and experimentation with LLM applicationsWe will continue to add features to LangChain and provide other offerings that will:Make it easy to quickly prototype applications.Bridge the gap between prototyping and putting something into production.We’re incredibly excited to see what will be built and to do more to support you. We are also especially grateful to the entire LangChain community. LangChain will continue to be open-source and focused on developers — our funding allows us to allocate more resources to take it to the next level. If this mission and journey sounds interesting to you, we are actively hiring founding engineers. If you have suggestions on new features or are interested in evaluating and running your LangChain applications in production, we’d especially love to hear from you at support@langchain.dev!Thank you for everything so far, and let’s build some cool stuff 🙂          Custom Agents        One of the most common requests we've heard is better functionality and documentation for creating custom agents. This has always been a bit tricky - because in our mind it's actually still very unclear what an "agent" actually is, and therefor what the "right" abstractions for them may be. Recently,Apr 3, 20233 min read          Retrieval        TL;DR: We are adjusting our abstractions to make it easy for other retrieval methods besides the LangChain VectorDB object to be used in LangChain. This is done with the goals of (1) allowing retrievers constructed elsewhere to be used more easily in LangChain, (2) encouraging more experimentation with alternativeMar 23, 20234 min read          LangChain + Zapier Natural Language Actions (NLA)        We are super excited to team up with Zapier and integrate their new Zapier NLA API into LangChain, which you can now use with your agents and chains. With this integration, you have access to the 5k+ apps and 20k+ actions on Zapier's platform through a natural language API interface.Mar 16, 20232 min readLangChain © 2023Sign upPowered by Ghost

Users note LangChain is outdated and copycats may disrupt the field, but others argue that frameworks are fluid and creative hackers could pursue new approaches. While some criticize the documentation, others recommend accompanying blog posts and suggest that AI-generated documentation could be a solution, utilizing LangChain itself.The tech industry is seeing a ferocious competition in the AI space with huge seed rounds being raised by Langchain and fixie.ai. However, some are concerned that the investment frenzy could lead to a commercial monopolization of the industry, leaving little room for true innovation. An HN user suggests that the VC-funded fiefdoms are not truly innovative and merely offer commercial applications of already developed scientific innovations. Despite the potential risks, many startups are cashing in on the GPT-3 wave, with chatbots being allowed for over a year. The future of Python in the face of a potential second AI winter and concerns over model weights being copyrightable is also under discussion.LangChain is an AI-based software library for composing LLM-powered systems together. The team has been funded with seed money and they plan to turn the library into a polished product by offering prebuilt hosted services for developers. The team will use monetization strategies such as consulting and paid plugins to generate revenue. Some users are concerned that LangChain may suffer the same fate as other open source projects that were tainted by VC cash. HN users discuss technical mitigations that can help foundation models stay in line with fair use, however, more research is needed to align mitigation strategies with the current state of the law. There is some confusion about the constructs of the LangChain codebase, despite its growing popularity. The use of pydantic is seen as un-pythonic and brittle to some users, despite others finding it essential to validate requests.LangChain, a popular open-source tool for composing language models in AI, has raised $10 million in seed funding, much to the dismay of some developers who criticize FOSS projects raising VC funding. Some developers question the effectiveness of LangChain, claiming it is "haphazardly slapped together" and only offers standardization of composing language model prompts. Despite this, LangChain is considered the most mature tool in the growing LLM revolution and expects to use the funding to expand the project’s ecosystem and better serve the community. Some developers note the need for more documentation, while others predict it could become the "backend" for many AI-based SaaS companies.Langchain has raised a $10 million seed round, prompting concerns among some contributors that the project's incentives may have shifted away from open source towards a for-profit business model. Some commenters criticize the project's documentation and urge contributors to fork the codebase. Others are optimistic about the project's potential and congratulate the team on their progress. The investment is seen as a bet on Langchain's vision, and some express interest in potential job opportunities. There are concerns about Langchain's monetization strategy and competition in the field.
